trans-unit.source: B4X is a suite of BASIC programming languages for different platforms.
trans-unit.target: B4X is a suite of BASIC programming languages for different platforms.

trans-unit.source: B4X suite supports more platforms than any other tool
trans-unit.target: B4X suite supports more platforms than any other tool

trans-unit.source: ANDROID | IOS | WINDOWS | MAC | LINUX | ARDUINO | RASPBERRY PI | ESP8266 | AND MORE...
trans-unit.target: ANDROID | IOS | WINDOWS | MAC | LINUX | ARDUINO | RASPBERRY PI | ESP8266 | AND MORE...

trans-unit.source: B4A AndroidB4A is a 100% free development tool for Android applications, it includes all the features needed to quickly develop any type of Android app.
trans-unit.target: B4A AndroidB4A is a 100% free development tool for Android applications, it includes all the features needed to quickly develop any type of Android app.

trans-unit.source: B4iiOSB4i is a development tool for native iOS applications.B4i follows the same concepts as B4A, allowing you to reuse most of the code and build apps for both Android and iOS.
trans-unit.target: B4iiOSB4i is a development tool for native iOS applications.B4i follows the same concepts as B4A, allowing you to reuse most of the code and build apps for both Android and iOS.

trans-unit.source: B4JJava / Windows / Mac / Linux / Raspberry PIB4J is a 100% free development tool for desktop, server and IoT solutions.With B4J you can easily create desktop applications (UI), console programs (non-UI) and server solutions.The compiled apps can run on Windows, Mac, Linux and ARM boards (such as Raspberry Pi).
trans-unit.target: B4JJava / Windows / Mac / Linux / Raspberry PIB4J is a 100% free development tool for desktop, server and IoT solutions.With B4J you can easily create desktop applications (UI), console programs (non-UI) and server solutions.The compiled apps can run on Windows, Mac, Linux and ARM boards (such as Raspberry Pi).

trans-unit.source: B4R Arduino / ESP8266B4R is a 100% free development tool for native Arduino and ESP8266 programs.B4R follows the same concepts of the other B4X tools, providing a simple and powerful development tool.B4R, B4A, B4J and B4i together make the best development solution for the Internet of Things (IoT).
trans-unit.target: B4R Arduino / ESP8266B4R is a 100% free development tool for native Arduino and ESP8266 programs.B4R follows the same concepts of the other B4X tools, providing a simple and powerful development tool.B4R, B4A, B4J and B4i together make the best development solution for the Internet of Things (IoT).

trans-unit.source: B4XPagesB4XPages is an internal library for B4A, B4i and B4J allowing to develop easily cross-platform programs.B4XPages is explained in detail in the B4XPages Cross-platform projects booklet.Even, if you want to develop only in one platform it is interesting to use the B4XPages library it makes the program flow simpler especially for B4A.
trans-unit.target: B4XPagesB4XPages is an internal library for B4A, B4i and B4J allowing to develop easily cross-platform programs.B4XPages is explained in detail in the B4XPages Cross-platform projects booklet.Even, if you want to develop only in one platform it is interesting to use the B4XPages library it makes the program flow simpler especially for B4A.

trans-unit.source: B4A (Basic for Android) is a simple yet powerful development environment that targets Android devices.B4A language is similar to Visual Basic language with additional support for objects.B4A compiled applications are native Android applications; there are no extra runtimes or dependencies.Unlike other IDE’s, B4A is 100% focused on Android development.B4A includes a powerful GUI designer with built-in support for multiple screens and orientations.
trans-unit.target: B4A (Basic for Android) is a simple yet powerful development environment that targets Android devices.B4A language is similar to Visual Basic language with additional support for objects.B4A compiled applications are native Android applications; there are no extra runtimes or dependencies.Unlike other IDE’s, B4A is 100% focused on Android development.B4A includes a powerful GUI designer with built-in support for multiple screens and orientations.

trans-unit.source: You can develop and debug with:
trans-unit.target: You can develop and debug with:

trans-unit.source: - a real device connected via B4A Bridge
trans-unit.target: - a real device connected via B4A Bridge

trans-unit.source: - a real device connected via USB cable
trans-unit.target: - a real device connected via USB cable

trans-unit.source: B4A has a rich set of libraries that make it easy to develop advanced applications. This includes: SQL databases, GPS, Serial ports (Bluetooth), Camera, XML parsing, Web services (HTTP), Services (background tasks), JSON, Animations, Network (TCP and UDP), Text To Speech (TTS), Voice Recognition, WebView, AdMob (ads), Charts, OpenGL, Graphics and more.
trans-unit.target: B4A has a rich set of libraries that make it easy to develop advanced applications. This includes: SQL databases, GPS, Serial ports (Bluetooth), Camera, XML parsing, Web services (HTTP), Services (background tasks), JSON, Animations, Network (TCP and UDP), Text To Speech (TTS), Voice Recognition, WebView, AdMob (ads), Charts, OpenGL, Graphics and more.

trans-unit.source: Android 1.6 and above are supported (including tablets).
trans-unit.target: Android 1.6 and above are supported (including tablets).

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.

trans-unit.source: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:
trans-unit.target: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:

trans-unit.source: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.
trans-unit.target: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.

trans-unit.source: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.
trans-unit.target: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.

trans-unit.source: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.
trans-unit.target: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.

trans-unit.source: This folder must have following structure:
trans-unit.target: This folder must have following structure:

trans-unit.source: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.
trans-unit.target: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.

trans-unit.source: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.
trans-unit.target: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.

trans-unit.source: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.
trans-unit.target: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.

trans-unit.source: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.
trans-unit.target: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.

trans-unit.source: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.
trans-unit.target: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.

trans-unit.source: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.
trans-unit.target: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.
trans-unit.target: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.

trans-unit.source: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.
trans-unit.target: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.

trans-unit.source: Libraries and modules are explained in the B4X Basic Language booklet.
trans-unit.target: Libraries and modules are explained in the B4X Basic Language booklet.

trans-unit.source: You can select a language of your choice, if it is available.
trans-unit.target: You can select a language of your choice, if it is available.

trans-unit.target: In the IDE menu Tools / IDE Options / Language select the language of your choice.

trans-unit.source: There are different means to connect a real device:
trans-unit.target: There are different means to connect a real device:

trans-unit.source: USBNeeds that the device supports ADB debugging.Need to activate USB Debugging on the device.
trans-unit.target: USBNeeds that the device supports ADB debugging.Need to activate USB Debugging on the device.

trans-unit.source: If you followed the previous steps, the Google USB driver is already download by default.
trans-unit.target: If you followed the previous steps, the Google USB driver is already download by default.

trans-unit.source: If this driver doesn’t work you must look for a specific one for your device.
trans-unit.target: If this driver doesn’t work you must look for a specific one for your device.

trans-unit.source: To be able to connect a device via USB you must activate USB debugging on the device.This is also needed if you use an Emulator.
trans-unit.target: To be able to connect a device via USB you must activate USB debugging on the device.This is also needed if you use an Emulator.

trans-unit.source: Scroll the screen until you see Developper options.
trans-unit.target: Scroll the screen until you see Developper options.

trans-unit.source: Scroll the screen until you see USB debugging.
trans-unit.target: Scroll the screen until you see USB debugging.

trans-unit.source: The device will automatically be recognized by the IDE.
trans-unit.target: The device will automatically be recognized by the IDE.

trans-unit.source: In this case, on some older devices, it was no more possible to access the SD card from the PC.
trans-unit.target: In this case, on some older devices, it was no more possible to access the SD card from the PC.

trans-unit.source: If you want to access the SD card you must deactivate USB debugging.
trans-unit.target: If you want to access the SD card you must deactivate USB debugging.

trans-unit.source: It is always recommended to use a real device instead of an Android emulator which is very slow compared to a real device (especially with applications installation).
trans-unit.target: It is always recommended to use a real device instead of an Android emulator which is very slow compared to a real device (especially with applications installation).

trans-unit.source: However not all devices support ADB debugging. This is the reason for the B4A-Bridge tool.
trans-unit.target: However not all devices support ADB debugging. This is the reason for the B4A-Bridge tool.

trans-unit.source: B4A-Bridge is made of two components. One component runs on the device and allows the second component which is part of the IDE to connect and communicate with the device.
trans-unit.target: B4A-Bridge is made of two components. One component runs on the device and allows the second component which is part of the IDE to connect and communicate with the device.

trans-unit.source: The connection is done over a network (B4A-Bridge cannot work if there is no network available).
trans-unit.target: The connection is done over a network (B4A-Bridge cannot work if there is no network available).

trans-unit.source: Once connected, B4A-Bridge supports all of the IDE features which include: installing applications, viewing LogCat and the visual designer.
trans-unit.target: Once connected, B4A-Bridge supports all of the IDE features which include: installing applications, viewing LogCat and the visual designer.

trans-unit.source: Android doesn't allow applications to quietly install other applications, therefore when you run your application using B4A-Bridge you will see a dialog asking for your approval.
trans-unit.target: Android doesn't allow applications to quietly install other applications, therefore when you run your application using B4A-Bridge you will see a dialog asking for your approval.

trans-unit.source: First you need to install B4A-Bridge on your device.
trans-unit.target: First you need to install B4A-Bridge on your device.

trans-unit.target: B4A-Bridge is also available on Play Store. Search for: B4A Bridge.

trans-unit.source: On this screen you should choose to start the application.If you try to install an existing application signed with a different key, the install will fail (without any meaningful message). trans-unit.source: - 1 EditText view where the user must enter the result.
trans-unit.target: - 1 EditText view where the user must enter the result.

trans-unit.target: - 1 Button, used to either confirm when the user has finished entering the result or generate a new calculation.

trans-unit.source: - 1 Label with a comment about the result.
trans-unit.target: - 1 Label with a comment about the result.

trans-unit.target: - Buttonis an object allowing user actions.

trans-unit.source: B4i is a simple yet powerful development environment that targets Apple devices (iPhone, iPad etc.).The B4i language is similar to Visual Basic and B4A language.B4i compiled applications are native iOS applications; there are no extra runtimes or dependencies.Unlike other IDE’s, B4i is 100% focused on iOS.B4i includes a powerful GUI designer, built-in support for multiple screens and orientations. You can develop and debug with a real device.
trans-unit.target: B4i is a simple yet powerful development environment that targets Apple devices (iPhone, iPad etc.).The B4i language is similar to Visual Basic and B4A language.B4i compiled applications are native iOS applications; there are no extra runtimes or dependencies.Unlike other IDE’s, B4i is 100% focused on iOS.B4i includes a powerful GUI designer, built-in support for multiple screens and orientations. You can develop and debug with a real device.

trans-unit.source: iOS compilation requires an Apple Mac computer. Developers have two options with B4i:
trans-unit.target: iOS compilation requires an Apple Mac computer. Developers have two options with B4i:

trans-unit.source: Use a local Mac machine connected over the local network. For this you should also download the Mac builder and install it.
trans-unit.target: Use a local Mac machine connected over the local network. For this you should also download the Mac builder and install it.

trans-unit.source: Use our hosted builder rental service. Hosted Mac Builder installation.The builder service allows you to develop iOS applications without a Mac computer.All of the development steps can be done with the builder service except of the final step which is uploading the application to Apple App Store. This step requires a Mac or a service such as MacInCloud.Note that the builder is currently limited to projects of up to 15mb.
trans-unit.target: Use our hosted builder rental service. Hosted Mac Builder installation.The builder service allows you to develop iOS applications without a Mac computer.All of the development steps can be done with the builder service except of the final step which is uploading the application to Apple App Store. This step requires a Mac or a service such as MacInCloud.Note that the builder is currently limited to projects of up to 15mb.

trans-unit.target: Link to the tutorial in the forum: Local Mac Builder Installation.

trans-unit.source: These instructions explain how to install the builder on a local Mac machine.1. Install Java JDK 8: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk8-downloads-2133151.html2. Install Xcode 6.3. Download and unzip the B4i-Builder.4. Open a terminal and navigate to B4i-Builder folder.5. Run it with: java -jar B4iBuildServer.jar6. Set the builder IP address in the IDE under Tools - Build Server - Server SettingsNotes & Tips- By default ports numbers 51041 (http) and 51042 (https) are used.- The firewall should be either disabled or allow incoming connections on these two ports.- You can test that the server is running by going to the following link: http://<server ip>:51041/test- You can kill the server with: http://<server ip>:51041/kill- It is recommended to set your Mac server ip address to a static address. This can be done in your router settings or in the Mac under Network settings.- A single Mac builder can serve multiple developers as long as they are all connected to the same local network. Note that you are not allowed to host builders for developers outside of your organization.Multiple IPs.When the server is started it takes the first IP address reported by the OS and uses it as its own IP address. You can see this address in the server messages.In most cases this is the correct address. However if it is not the correct IP address then the server will not be usable.In that case you need to explicitly set the correct address: - Open the key folder and delete all files.- Edit key.txt and change it to: manuel:<correct ip address>
trans-unit.target: These instructions explain how to install the builder on a local Mac machine.1. Install Java JDK 8: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk8-downloads-2133151.html2. Install Xcode 6.3. Download and unzip the B4i-Builder.4. Open a terminal and navigate to B4i-Builder folder.5. Run it with: java -jar B4iBuildServer.jar6. Set the builder IP address in the IDE under Tools - Build Server - Server SettingsNotes & Tips- By default ports numbers 51041 (http) and 51042 (https) are used.- The firewall should be either disabled or allow incoming connections on these two ports.- You can test that the server is running by going to the following link: http://<server ip>:51041/test- You can kill the server with: http://<server ip>:51041/kill- It is recommended to set your Mac server ip address to a static address. This can be done in your router settings or in the Mac under Network settings.- A single Mac builder can serve multiple developers as long as they are all connected to the same local network. Note that you are not allowed to host builders for developers outside of your organization.Multiple IPs.When the server is started it takes the first IP address reported by the OS and uses it as its own IP address. You can see this address in the server messages.In most cases this is the correct address. However if it is not the correct IP address then the server will not be usable.In that case you need to explicitly set the correct address: - Open the key folder and delete all files.- Edit key.txt and change it to: manuel:<correct ip address>

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.

trans-unit.source: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:
trans-unit.target: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:

trans-unit.source: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.
trans-unit.target: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.

trans-unit.source: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.
trans-unit.target: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.

trans-unit.source: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.
trans-unit.target: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.

trans-unit.source: This folder must have following structure:
trans-unit.target: This folder must have following structure:

trans-unit.source: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.
trans-unit.target: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.

trans-unit.source: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.
trans-unit.target: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.

trans-unit.source: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.
trans-unit.target: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.

trans-unit.source: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.
trans-unit.target: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.

trans-unit.source: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.
trans-unit.target: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.

trans-unit.source: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.
trans-unit.target: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.
trans-unit.target: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.

trans-unit.source: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.
trans-unit.target: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.

trans-unit.target: Libraries and modules are explained in the B4X Basic Language booklet.

trans-unit.source: Creating a certificate and provisioning profile
trans-unit.target: Creating a certificate and provisioning profile

trans-unit.source: Don't panic!While this process can be a bit annoying it is not too complicated and you can always delete the keys and start from scratch (which is not always the case in Android).Note that you must first register with Apple as an iOS developer (costs $99 per year).The whole process is done on a Windows computer.In order to install an app on an iOS device you need to create a certificate and a provisioning profile.The certificate is used to sign the application. The provisioning profile, which is tied to a specific certificate, includes a list of devices that this app can be installed on.The video shows the steps required for creating and downloading a certificate and provisioning profile.There are two steps which are not shown in the video and are also required before you can create a provisioning profile: - Create an App ID. This step is quite simple. Just make sure that you create a wildcard id.- Add one or more devices. You will need to find the devices UDID for that.
trans-unit.target: Don't panic!While this process can be a bit annoying it is not too complicated and you can always delete the keys and start from scratch (which is not always the case in Android).Note that you must first register with Apple as an iOS developer (costs $99 per year).The whole process is done on a Windows computer.In order to install an app on an iOS device you need to create a certificate and a provisioning profile.The certificate is used to sign the application. The provisioning profile, which is tied to a specific certificate, includes a list of devices that this app can be installed on.The video shows the steps required for creating and downloading a certificate and provisioning profile.There are two steps which are not shown in the video and are also required before you can create a provisioning profile: - Create an App ID. This step is quite simple. Just make sure that you create a wildcard id.- Add one or more devices. You will need to find the devices UDID for that.

trans-unit.target: Page1.Initialize("Page1")> Initializes Page1, "Page1" is the generic EventName of Page1.

trans-unit.source: We want to generate a new problem as soon as the program starts. Therefore, we add a call to the NewProblem subroutine in Application_Start.
trans-unit.target: We want to generate a new problem as soon as the program starts. Therefore, we add a call to the NewProblem subroutine in Application_Start.

trans-unit.target: NewProblem is displayed in red because the ‘NewProblem’ routine has not yet been defined.

trans-unit.source: Generating a new problem means generating two new random values between 1 and 9 (inclusive) for Number1 and Number2, then showing the values using the lblNumber1 and lblNumber2 ‘Text’ properties.
trans-unit.target: Generating a new problem means generating two new random values between 1 and 9 (inclusive) for Number1 and Number2, then showing the values using the lblNumber1 and lblNumber2 ‘Text’ properties.

trans-unit.source: To do this we enter following code:
trans-unit.target: To do this we enter following code:

trans-unit.source: In Sub Process_Globals we add two variables for the two numbers.
trans-unit.target: In Sub Process_Globals we add two variables for the two numbers.

trans-unit.source: Number1 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9
trans-unit.target: Number1 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9

trans-unit.source: Number2 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9
trans-unit.target: Number2 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9

trans-unit.source: lblNumber1.Text = Number1' Displays Number1 in label lblNumber1
trans-unit.target: lblNumber1.Text = Number1' Displays Number1 in label lblNumber1

trans-unit.source: lblNumber2.Text = Number2' Displays Number2 in label lblNumber2
trans-unit.target: lblNumber2.Text = Number2' Displays Number2 in label lblNumber2

trans-unit.source: lblComments.Text = "Enter the result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"
trans-unit.target: lblComments.Text = "Enter the result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"

trans-unit.target: In this line Number1 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9

trans-unit.source: Now we add the code for the Button click event.

trans-unit.source: - When the Button text is equal to "O K", it means that a new problem is displayed, and the program is waiting for the user to enter a result and press the Button.
trans-unit.target: - When the Button text is equal to "O K", it means that a new problem is displayed, and the program is waiting for the user to enter a result and press the Button.

trans-unit.source: - When the Button text is equal to "NEW", it means that the user has entered a correct answer and when the user clicks on the Button a new problem will be generated.
trans-unit.target: - When the Button text is equal to "NEW", it means that the user has entered a correct answer and when the user clicks on the Button a new problem will be generated.

trans-unit.target: If btnAction.Text = "O K" Then checks if the Button text equals "O K"

trans-unit.target: If no, we check if the result is correct or if it is wrong.

trans-unit.source: B4J is a 100% free development tool for desktop, server and IoT solutions.With B4J you can easily create desktop applications (UI), console programs (non-UI) and server solutions.The compiled apps can run on Windows, Mac, Linux and ARM boards (such as Raspberry Pi).
trans-unit.target: B4J is a 100% free development tool for desktop, server and IoT solutions.With B4J you can easily create desktop applications (UI), console programs (non-UI) and server solutions.The compiled apps can run on Windows, Mac, Linux and ARM boards (such as Raspberry Pi).

trans-unit.source: The B4J language is like Visual Basic and B4A language.B4J includes a powerful GUI designer, built-in support for multiple screens and orientations.
trans-unit.target: The B4J language is like Visual Basic and B4A language.B4J includes a powerful GUI designer, built-in support for multiple screens and orientations.

trans-unit.source: The B4J program, this is a Windows program running on a PC.
trans-unit.target: The B4J program, this is a Windows program running on a PC.

trans-unit.source: The Java SDK on the PC, free.
trans-unit.target: The Java SDK on the PC, free.

trans-unit.source: The most up to date installation instructions are in the forum at this link: www.b4x.com/b4j.html.Please, follow the instructions there!
trans-unit.target: The most up to date installation instructions are in the forum at this link: www.b4x.com/b4j.html.Please, follow the instructions there!

trans-unit.source: Download and install the B4J file on your computer.
trans-unit.target: Download and install the B4J file on your computer.

trans-unit.source: As B4J is for free, there is no license file needed like for B4A and B4i.
trans-unit.target: As B4J is for free, there is no license file needed like for B4A and B4i.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on run.exe will run the program.run_debug.bat will run the program with a console window.An Inno Setup script template is created in the parent folder. You can use it to build a single file installer.Notes- B4JPackager11 supports Windows 64 bit. Support for Mac and Linux will be added in the future. Windows 32 bit is not supported by Java 11.- B4JPackager11 creates a folder named temp in the Objects folder. If such folder already exists it deletes it.- A new version of B4J-Bridge was released (v1.40). It is required for Java 11. If you are running Java 11 on the PC then you should also run Java 11 on the remote computer.- Runnable jars are not supported in Java 11+.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on run.exe will run the program.run_debug.bat will run the program with a console window.An Inno Setup script template is created in the parent folder. You can use it to build a single file installer.Notes- B4JPackager11 supports Windows 64 bit. Support for Mac and Linux will be added in the future. Windows 32 bit is not supported by Java 11.- B4JPackager11 creates a folder named temp in the Objects folder. If such folder already exists it deletes it.- A new version of B4J-Bridge was released (v1.40). It is required for Java 11. If you are running Java 11 on the PC then you should also run Java 11 on the remote computer.- Runnable jars are not supported in Java 11+.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.

trans-unit.source: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:
trans-unit.target: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:

trans-unit.source: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.
trans-unit.target: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.

trans-unit.source: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.
trans-unit.target: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.

trans-unit.source: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.
trans-unit.target: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.

trans-unit.source: This folder must have following structure:
trans-unit.target: This folder must have following structure:

trans-unit.source: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.
trans-unit.target: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.

trans-unit.source: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.
trans-unit.target: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.

trans-unit.source: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.
trans-unit.target: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.

trans-unit.source: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.
trans-unit.target: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.

trans-unit.source: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.
trans-unit.target: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.

trans-unit.source: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.
trans-unit.target: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.
trans-unit.target: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.

trans-unit.source: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.
trans-unit.target: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.

trans-unit.source: Event Name :generic name of the routines that handle the events of the Label.

trans-unit.source: Generating a new problem means generating two new random values between 1 and 9 (inclusive) for Number1 and Number2, then showing the values using the lblNumber1 and lblNumber2 ‘Text’ properties.
trans-unit.target: Generating a new problem means generating two new random values between 1 and 9 (inclusive) for Number1 and Number2, then showing the values using the lblNumber1 and lblNumber2 ‘Text’ properties.

trans-unit.source: To do this we enter following code:
trans-unit.target: To do this we enter following code:

trans-unit.source: In Sub Process_Globals we add two variables for the two numbers.
trans-unit.target: In Sub Process_Globals we add two variables for the two numbers.

trans-unit.source: Number1 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9
trans-unit.target: Number1 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9

trans-unit.source: Number2 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9
trans-unit.target: Number2 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9

trans-unit.source: lblNumber1.Text = Number1' Displays Number1 in label lblNumber1
trans-unit.target: lblNumber1.Text = Number1' Displays Number1 in label lblNumber1

trans-unit.source: lblNumber2.Text = Number2' Displays Number2 in label lblNumber2
trans-unit.target: lblNumber2.Text = Number2' Displays Number2 in label lblNumber2

trans-unit.source: lblComments.Text = "Enter the result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"
trans-unit.target: lblComments.Text = "Enter the result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"

trans-unit.source: The following line of code generates a random number from '1' (inclusive) to '10' (exclusive) :
trans-unit.target: The following line of code generates a random number from '1' (inclusive) to '10' (exclusive) :

trans-unit.target: In this line Number1 = Rnd(1, 10)' Generates a random number between 1 and 9

trans-unit.target: lblComments.Text = "Enter the result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"

trans-unit.source: Now we add the code for the Button click event.
trans-unit.target: Now we add the code for the Button click event.

trans-unit.source: - When the Button text is equal to "O K", it means that a new problem is displayed, and the program is waiting for the user to enter a result and press the Button.
trans-unit.target: - When the Button text is equal to "O K", it means that a new problem is displayed, and the program is waiting for the user to enter a result and press the Button.

trans-unit.source: - When the Button text is equal to "NEW", it means that the user has entered a correct answer and when the user clicks on the Button a new problem will be generated.
trans-unit.target: - When the Button text is equal to "NEW", it means that the user has entered a correct answer and when the user clicks on the Button a new problem will be generated.

trans-unit.source: lblComments.Text = "No result entered" & CRLF & "Enter a result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"
trans-unit.target: lblComments.Text = "No result entered" & CRLF & "Enter a result" & CRLF & "and click on OK"

trans-unit.source: If btnAction.Text = "O K" Then checks if the Button text equals "O K".
trans-unit.target: If btnAction.Text = "O K" Then checks if the Button text equals "O K".

trans-unit.source: If yes, we check if the TextField is empty.
trans-unit.target: If yes, we check if the TextField is empty.

trans-unit.source: If yes, we display a message in the comment field telling the user that there is no result in the TextField node.
trans-unit.target: If yes, we display a message in the comment field telling the user that there is no result in the TextField node.

trans-unit.source: If no, we check if the result is correct or if it is wrong.
trans-unit.target: If no, we check if the result is correct or if it is wrong.

trans-unit.source: If no, we generate a new problem, set the Button text to "O K" and clear the TextField node.
trans-unit.target: If no, we generate a new problem, set the Button text to "O K" and clear the TextField node.

trans-unit.source: The last routine checks the result.
trans-unit.target: The last routine checks the result.

trans-unit.source: lblComments.Text = "G O O D result" & CRLF & "Click on NEW"
trans-unit.target: lblComments.Text = "G O O D result" & CRLF & "Click on NEW"

trans-unit.source: lblComments.Text = "W R O N G result" & CRLF & "Enter a new result" & CRLF & "and click OK"
trans-unit.target: lblComments.Text = "W R O N G result" & CRLF & "Enter a new result" & CRLF & "and click OK"

source.g: B4R - The simplest way to develop native, powerful Arduino programs.

target.g: B4R - The simplest way to develop native, powerful Arduino programs.

trans-unit.source: B4R follows the same concepts of the other B4X tools (B4A, B4i, B4J), providing a simple and powerful development tool.
trans-unit.target: B4R follows the same concepts of the other B4X tools (B4A, B4i, B4J), providing a simple and powerful development tool.

trans-unit.source: Compiled apps run on Arduino compatible boards.
trans-unit.target: Compiled apps run on Arduino compatible boards.

trans-unit.source: B4R needs the installation of Arduino IDE version 1.8+.
trans-unit.target: B4R needs the installation of Arduino IDE version 1.8+.

trans-unit.source: Download Arduino IDE from this link: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Donate and install it.
trans-unit.target: Download Arduino IDE from this link: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Donate and install it.

trans-unit.source: You should not install Arduino from this site: http://www.arduino.org/downloads
trans-unit.target: You should not install Arduino from this site: http://www.arduino.org/downloads

trans-unit.source: On most computers Microsoft .Net Framework is already preinstalled.
trans-unit.target: On most computers Microsoft .Net Framework is already preinstalled.

trans-unit.source: If it is not the case, you must install either:
trans-unit.target: If it is not the case, you must install either:

trans-unit.source: - Open B4R.- Choose Tools menu - Configure Paths.
trans-unit.target: - Open B4R.- Choose Tools menu - Configure Paths.

trans-unit.source: Use the button to locate "arduino.exe". The path will depend on where you installed the Arduino IDE.
trans-unit.target: Use the button to locate "arduino.exe". The path will depend on where you installed the Arduino IDE.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to create a specific folder for Additional libraries.

trans-unit.source: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:
trans-unit.target: B4A utilizes two types of libraries:

trans-unit.source: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.
trans-unit.target: Standard libraries, which come with B4A and are located in theLibraries folder of B4A. These libraries are automatically updated when you install a new version of B4A.

trans-unit.source: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.
trans-unit.target: Additional libraries, which are not part of B4A, and are mostly written by members. These libraries should be saved in a specific folder different from the standard libraries folder.

trans-unit.source: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.
trans-unit.target: For the additional libraries it is necessary to setup a special folder to save them somewhere else.

trans-unit.source: This folder must have following structure:
trans-unit.target: This folder must have following structure:

trans-unit.source: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.
trans-unit.target: Folder for B4X libraries XML files.

trans-unit.source: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.
trans-unit.target: One subfolder for each product: B4A, B4i, B4J, B4R and another B4X for B4X libraries.

trans-unit.source: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: When you install a new version of a B4X product, all standard libraries are automatically updated, but the additional libraries are not included. The advantage of the special folder is that you don't need to care about them because this folder is not affected when you install the new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.
trans-unit.target: The additional libraries are not systematically updated with new version of B4X.

trans-unit.source: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.
trans-unit.target: When the IDE starts, it looks first for the available libraries in the Libraries folder of B4X and then in the additional libraries folders.

trans-unit.source: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.
trans-unit.target: In my system, I added a B4XlibXMLFiles folder for XML help files.

trans-unit.source: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.
trans-unit.target: The standard and additional libraries have an XML file. B4X Libraies not.

trans-unit.source: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.
trans-unit.target: But, if you use the B4X Help Viewer you would be interested in having these help files if they are available.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.
trans-unit.target: Create a specific folder for shared modules, for example C:\B4J\SharedModules.

trans-unit.source: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.
trans-unit.target: Module files can be shared between different projects and must therefore be saved in a specific folder.

trans-unit.source: Libraries and modules are explained in the B4X Basic Language booklet.
trans-unit.target: Libraries and modules are explained in the B4X Basic Language booklet.

trans-unit.target: When you connect a board to the PC with the USB cable Windows will load the driver and display the Serial port used.

trans-unit.target: The window below will be displayed.

trans-unit.target: Select the Board Type in the drop down list.

trans-unit.source: Select the Serial Port and select the Baud Rate.
trans-unit.target: Select the Serial Port and select the Baud Rate.

trans-unit.source: If only one board is connected it will automatically be recognized.
trans-unit.target: If only one board is connected it will automatically be recognized.

trans-unit.source: You will see only boards which are connected.
trans-unit.target: You will see only boards which are connected.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the board type several other properties can be set.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the board type several other properties can be set.

trans-unit.source: In this chapter I will explain some basic functions of the Arduino UNO board which may be useful for beginners.
trans-unit.target: In this chapter I will explain some basic functions of the Arduino UNO board which may be useful for beginners.

trans-unit.source: The Arduino UNO board is the basic board of the Arduino family.
trans-unit.target: The Arduino UNO board is the basic board of the Arduino family.

trans-unit.source: There exist other more advanced boards.
trans-unit.target: There exist other more advanced boards.

trans-unit.source: Additional boards called ‘Shields’ can be clipped onto the Arduino boards.
trans-unit.target: Additional boards called ‘Shields’ can be clipped onto the Arduino boards.

trans-unit.source: The source of the information in this chapter is a summary from the Arduino site.
trans-unit.target: The source of the information in this chapter is a summary from the Arduino site.

trans-unit.source: The board can be supplied with power either from the DC power jack (7 - 12V), the USB connector (5V), or the VIN pin of the board (7-12V).
trans-unit.target: The board can be supplied with power either from the DC power jack (7 - 12V), the USB connector (5V), or the VIN pin of the board (7-12V).

trans-unit.source: Supplying voltage via the 5V or 3.3V pins bypasses the regulator, and can damage your board (see the pins below). We don't advise it.
trans-unit.target: Supplying voltage via the 5V or 3.3V pins bypasses the regulator, and can damage your board (see the pins below). We don't advise it.

trans-unit.source: The Arduino UNO has 3 pin sockets:
trans-unit.target: The Arduino UNO has 3 pin sockets:

trans-unit.source: VINPower supply input.The input voltage to the Uno board when it's using an external power source (as opposed to 5 volts from the USB connection or other regulated power source). You can supply voltage through this pin, or, if supplying voltage via the power jack, access it through this pin.Voltage 7 – 12 V.
trans-unit.target: VINPower supply input.The input voltage to the Uno board when it's using an external power source (as opposed to 5 volts from the USB connection or other regulated power source). You can supply voltage through this pin, or, if supplying voltage via the power jack, access it through this pin.Voltage 7 – 12 V.

trans-unit.source: 5V 5 Volt reference voltage. Don’t provide the power to this pin!This pin outputs a regulated 5V from the regulator on the board.
trans-unit.target: 5V 5 Volt reference voltage. Don’t provide the power to this pin!This pin outputs a regulated 5V from the regulator on the board.

trans-unit.source: 3.3V3.3 Volt reference voltage. Don’t provide the power to this pin!A 3.3 volt supply generated by the on-board regulator. Maximum current draw is 50 mA.
trans-unit.target: 3.3V3.3 Volt reference voltage. Don’t provide the power to this pin!A 3.3 volt supply generated by the on-board regulator. Maximum current draw is 50 mA.

trans-unit.source: RESETBring this line LOW to reset the microcontroller. Typically used to add a reset button to shields which block the one on the board.
trans-unit.target: RESETBring this line LOW to reset the microcontroller. Typically used to add a reset button to shields which block the one on the board.

trans-unit.source: IOREFThis pin on the Uno board provides the voltage reference with which the microcontroller operates. A properly configured shield can read the IOREF pin voltage and select the appropriate power source or enable voltage translators on the outputs to work with the 5V or 3.3V.
trans-unit.target: IOREFThis pin on the Uno board provides the voltage reference with which the microcontroller operates. A properly configured shield can read the IOREF pin voltage and select the appropriate power source or enable voltage translators on the outputs to work with the 5V or 3.3V.

trans-unit.source: Each of the 14 digital pins on the Uno can be used as an input or output, using the pinMode method, DigitalRead and DigitalWrite functions. They operate at 5 volts. Each pin can provide or receive 20 mA as recommended operating condition and has an internal pull-up resistor (disconnected by default) of 20-50 kohm. A maximum of 40mA is the value that must not be exceeded on any I/O pin to avoid permanent damage to the microcontroller.
trans-unit.target: Each of the 14 digital pins on the Uno can be used as an input or output, using the pinMode method, DigitalRead and DigitalWrite functions. They operate at 5 volts. Each pin can provide or receive 20 mA as recommended operating condition and has an internal pull-up resistor (disconnected by default) of 20-50 kohm. A maximum of 40mA is the value that must not be exceeded on any I/O pin to avoid permanent damage to the microcontroller.

trans-unit.source: In addition, some pins have specialized functions:
trans-unit.target: In addition, some pins have specialized functions:

trans-unit.source: Serial: 0 (RX) and 1 (TX). Used to receive (RX) and transmit (TX) TTL serial data. These pins are connected to the corresponding pins of the ATmega8U2 USB-to-TTL Serial chip.
trans-unit.target: Serial: 0 (RX) and 1 (TX). Used to receive (RX) and transmit (TX) TTL serial data. These pins are connected to the corresponding pins of the ATmega8U2 USB-to-TTL Serial chip.

trans-unit.source: PWM: ~3, ~5, ~6, ~9, ~10, and ~11. These numbers have this “~” prefix.They can provide 8-bit PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) outputs with the AnalogWrite function allowing to modulate the brightness of a LED (Light Emitting Diode) or run DC motors at different speeds.A value of 0 means always OFF and 255 means always ON.Usage:pinTest3.AnalogWrite(Value As UInt)pinTest3.AnalogWrite(196)After AnalogWrite the pin will generate a steady square wave of the specified duty cycle until the next call to AnalogWrite (or a call to DigitalRead or DigitalWrite on the same pin). The frequency of the PWM signal on most pins is approximately 490 Hz. On the Uno and similar boards, pins 5 and 6 have a frequency of approximately 980 Hz. Pins 3 and 11 on the Leonardo also run at 980 Hz.
trans-unit.target: PWM: ~3, ~5, ~6, ~9, ~10, and ~11. These numbers have this “~” prefix.They can provide 8-bit PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) outputs with the AnalogWrite function allowing to modulate the brightness of a LED (Light Emitting Diode) or run DC motors at different speeds.A value of 0 means always OFF and 255 means always ON.Usage:pinTest3.AnalogWrite(Value As UInt)pinTest3.AnalogWrite(196)After AnalogWrite the pin will generate a steady square wave of the specified duty cycle until the next call to AnalogWrite (or a call to DigitalRead or DigitalWrite on the same pin). The frequency of the PWM signal on most pins is approximately 490 Hz. On the Uno and similar boards, pins 5 and 6 have a frequency of approximately 980 Hz. Pins 3 and 11 on the Leonardo also run at 980 Hz.

trans-unit.source: LED 13: There is a built-in LED driven by digital pin 13. When the pin is HIGH value, the LED is on, when the pin is LOW, it's off.
trans-unit.target: LED 13: There is a built-in LED driven by digital pin 13. When the pin is HIGH value, the LED is on, when the pin is LOW, it's off.

trans-unit.source: The Arduino UNO has 6 Analog input pins A0 to A5 with 10 bit analog to digital converters (0 to 1023 resolution).
trans-unit.target: The Arduino UNO has 6 Analog input pins A0 to A5 with 10 bit analog to digital converters (0 to 1023 resolution).

trans-unit.source: The reference voltage is 5 Volt allowing a resolution of 4.9 mV per unit.
trans-unit.target: The reference voltage is 5 Volt allowing a resolution of 4.9 mV per unit.

trans-unit.source: While the main function of the analog pins for most Arduino users is to read analog sensors, the analog pins also have all the functionality of general purpose input/output (GPIO) pins (the same as digital pins 0 - 13).
trans-unit.target: While the main function of the analog pins for most Arduino users is to read analog sensors, the analog pins also have all the functionality of general purpose input/output (GPIO) pins (the same as digital pins 0 - 13).

trans-unit.source: If you have your pin configured as an INPUT, and are reading a switch, when the switch is in the open state the input pin will be "floating", resulting in unpredictable results. In order to assure a proper reading when the switch is open, a pull-up or pull-down resistor must be used. The purpose of this resistor is to pull the pin to a known state when the switch is open. A 10 K ohm resistor is usually chosen, as it is a low enough value to reliably prevent a floating input, and at the same time a high enough value to not draw too much current when the switch is closed.
trans-unit.target: If you have your pin configured as an INPUT, and are reading a switch, when the switch is in the open state the input pin will be "floating", resulting in unpredictable results. In order to assure a proper reading when the switch is open, a pull-up or pull-down resistor must be used. The purpose of this resistor is to pull the pin to a known state when the switch is open. A 10 K ohm resistor is usually chosen, as it is a low enough value to reliably prevent a floating input, and at the same time a high enough value to not draw too much current when the switch is closed.

trans-unit.source: The INPUT_PULLUP mode adds an internal pull up resistor no need to add one externally.
trans-unit.target: The INPUT_PULLUP mode adds an internal pull up resistor no need to add one externally.

trans-unit.source: With a pull up resistor the pin returns False when the switch is closed because it sets the input to 0 Volt.
trans-unit.target: With a pull up resistor the pin returns False when the switch is closed because it sets the input to 0 Volt.

trans-unit.source: Writes a Boolean value to the given pin.
trans-unit.target: Writes a Boolean value to the given pin.

trans-unit.source: It can be used for all digital pins and also all analog pins.
trans-unit.target: It can be used for all digital pins and also all analog pins.

trans-unit.source: AnalogRead reads the current value of an analog pin.
trans-unit.target: AnalogRead reads the current value of an analog pin.

trans-unit.source: The return value is an UInt with values between 0 and 1023 (10 bits).
trans-unit.target: The return value is an UInt with values between 0 and 1023 (10 bits).

trans-unit.source: AnalogWrite writes a Byte value to the given pin.
trans-unit.target: AnalogWrite writes a Byte value to the given pin.

trans-unit.source: AnalogWrite has nothing to do with the analog pins nor with AnalogRead.
trans-unit.target: AnalogWrite has nothing to do with the analog pins nor with AnalogRead.

trans-unit.source: AnalogWrite can only be used on the digital pins ~3, ~5, ~6, ~9, ~10, and ~11 on the Arduino UNO, the pins with the ~ prefix.
trans-unit.target: AnalogWrite can only be used on the digital pins ~3, ~5, ~6, ~9, ~10, and ~11 on the Arduino UNO, the pins with the ~ prefix.

trans-unit.source: Example: we use digital pin ~3 which allows PWM.
trans-unit.target: Example: we use digital pin ~3 which allows PWM.

trans-unit.source: It’s similar to Erels Button example from the forum. It uses a pushbutton switch and the Led 13 on the Arduino UNO board.
trans-unit.target: It’s similar to Erels Button example from the forum. It uses a pushbutton switch and the Led 13 on the Arduino UNO board.

trans-unit.source: The project Button.b4r is available in the SourceCode folder.
trans-unit.target: The project Button.b4r is available in the SourceCode folder.

trans-unit.source: Save the project as Button in a folder with the name Button.
trans-unit.target: Save the project as Button in a folder with the name Button.

trans-unit.target: Build the board with the pushbutton and the wires.

trans-unit.source: Connect the Arduino to the PC.
trans-unit.target: Connect the Arduino to the PC.

trans-unit.source: Connect one Arduino GND (ground) pin to the ground GND line of the breadboard.
trans-unit.target: Connect one Arduino GND (ground) pin to the ground GND line of the breadboard.

trans-unit.source: Then connect one pin of the pushbutton switch to the ground line.
trans-unit.target: Then connect one pin of the pushbutton switch to the ground line.

trans-unit.source: And connect the other pin of the pushbutton to pin A5 of the Arduino analog pins.
trans-unit.target: And connect the other pin of the pushbutton to pin A5 of the Arduino analog pins.

trans-unit.source: We could have connected the first pin of the pushbutton directly to the GDN pin of the Arduino, but the connection in the image is ready for the next examples.
trans-unit.target: We could have connected the first pin of the pushbutton directly to the GDN pin of the Arduino, but the connection in the image is ready for the next examples.

trans-unit.source: We could also have used one of the digital pins instead of the analog pin.
trans-unit.target: We could also have used one of the digital pins instead of the analog pin.

trans-unit.target: We initialize pinLED13, as the onboard Led as digital pin 13 and set the output mode to pinLED13.MODE_OUTPUT.

trans-unit.target: We add a Log, Log("State: ", State), to display the state in the Logs.

trans-unit.target: We write the State to the digital output of the on board led, pinLED13.DigitalWrite(Not(State)).

trans-unit.source: The pushbutton switch we use in our projects has a problem called bouncing.
trans-unit.target: The pushbutton switch we use in our projects has a problem called bouncing.

trans-unit.source: The signal of a mecanical switch is not clean, the switch has several bounces which are interpreted by the the digital inputs as several state changes. If we have an even number of state changes it is similar to having done nothing.
trans-unit.target: The signal of a mecanical switch is not clean, the switch has several bounces which are interpreted by the the digital inputs as several state changes. If we have an even number of state changes it is similar to having done nothing.

trans-unit.source: But we want only one state change per button press.
trans-unit.target: But we want only one state change per button press.

trans-unit.source: The switch bounces between on and off several times before settling.
trans-unit.target: The switch bounces between on and off several times before settling.

trans-unit.source: To solve this problem we don’t react in the pinButton_StateChanged routine on state changes within a given time.
trans-unit.target: To solve this problem we don’t react in the pinButton_StateChanged routine on state changes within a given time.
